title: How to Level Up Your Clothing Skill in Elder Scrolls Online

steps.headline: Find crafting materials.
steps.description: As you travel in the wilderness, look around for materials that you can refine to make crafting materials. They are located everywhere in the wild and on monsters that you slay throughout the game. The kind of materials you will look for depends on whether you want to craft light or medium armor. The refining materials for light armor are Jute, Flax, Cotton, Spidersilk, Ebonthread, Famin, Ironthread, Silverweave, and Void Cloth. The materials that can be refined for medium armor is Rawhide, Leather, Thick Leather, Hide, Topgrain Hide,  Fell Hide, Iron Hide, Scaled Hide, and Daedra Hide.

steps.headline: Go into town and look for a Clothing Station.
steps.description: You can find them two ways: look at your map for a small icon that resembles a pair of scissors, or you can look for a table that has a hide stretched out on it along with scissors and other materials.

steps.headline: Open the Clothing Station menu.
steps.description: Once you find the station, walk up to it and hit the A button. This will open the Clothing menu.

steps.headline: Access the Refine menu.
steps.description: Hit the A button on the first option under the clothing table menu, which reads “Refine.” A new menu will pop up, and you can see all of the materials that you can refine on the left side of the screen.

steps.headline: Start refining an item.
steps.description: Highlight the item you want to refine and hit the X button. This will refine the material into something that you can use to craft armor. Every time you refine something, you will gain experience in your clothing skill tree.

steps.headline: Check your inventory and make sure you have all of the materials you need to craft light or medium armor.
steps.description: You are going to need crafting material, style gems, and trait gems if you wish to add a trait to your armor. Crafting material can be refined, or found in crates and bags around the world or on fallen enemies. Style gems can be found as you explore the world. Trait gems are harder to come across; you can find them from looting.

steps.headline: Find a Clothing Station.
steps.description: You can look at your map in any town and find it by looking for the icon that resembles a pair of scissors cutting thread. You could also walk around town and look for a table that has hide stretched across it, and scissors and other crafting materials on it.

steps.headline: Open the Clothing menu.
steps.description: When you find the Clothing Station, hit A to activate the Clothing menu.

steps.headline: Open the Creation menu.
steps.description: Select the second option down that says “Creation.” You will be shown a menu with four boxes that you have to make selections on before you can create armor.

steps.headline: Pick the item you want to make in the first box.
steps.description: You can make a robe, shirt, shoes, gloves, hats, breeches, arm caps, and more. Pick the item you want to make by going left or right on the controller until you highlight the item you want to create.

steps.headline: Select the material to use.
steps.description: Go to the second box, which is where you will select your material. Use the directional buttons to highlight the item, and press A.

steps.headline: Choose the style gem that you want to use.
steps.description: Each race has their own style, so use the appropriate gem for the proper style. For example, Khajits need moonstone for their style.

steps.headline: Pick a trait.
steps.description: You do not need to pick a trait, but having a trait on your item will make it stronger. You can add extra defense and buffs by using trait gems.

steps.headline: Start creating.
steps.description: Hit the X button to craft your item when you pick everything out for the piece of armor. Once the armor is crafted, you will get the item and a nice experience boost for your Clothing skill line.

steps.headline: Look in your inventory to see if you have items that can be deconstructed.
steps.description: Pretty much any light or medium armor can be deconstructed at a clothing station. Press the Start button and go to your inventory to find the items that you can take apart.

steps.headline: Locate a Clothing Station.
steps.description: You can find Clothing Stations in any major city. Look for a table with hide scraps and scissors on it; this is a Clothing Station. You can also check your map for a small pair of scissors cutting thread; this is where Clothing Stations are located.

steps.headline: Open the Clothing Menu.
steps.description: Walk up to the table and hit the A button. This will load the Clothing Station menu.

steps.headline: Access the Deconstruction menu.
steps.description: The third option down says “Deconstruct”. Select it and hit A to load up your items that can be deconstructed on the left side of the screen.

steps.headline: Deconstruct a clothing item.
steps.description: Highlight the item you want to deconstruct by moving your cursor over it and hitting the X button. You will lose the item, but if you look in the top right side of the screen, you will get items from the deconstruct as well as valuable experience for your Clothing skill line.

steps.headline: Look in your inventory for an item you want to improve.
steps.description: You can see if your currently equipped gear could use an improvement from your inventory as well. Hit the Start button and open your inventory to see your items. You can improve light and medium armor.

steps.headline: Find a Clothing Station.
steps.description: You can either look at your map for a pair of scissors cutting thread, or simply look for a table in town that has hide stretched over it and leather scraps scattered over it.

steps.headline: Activate the station.
steps.description: Walk up to the Clothing Station and hit the A button. This will open the clothing menu.

steps.headline: Open the Improvement menu.
steps.description: Go down to the fourth option that says “Improvement” and hit the A button. A list of your current items will open on the left side of the page.

steps.headline: Select an item to improve.
steps.description: Go to the item you want to improve and hit the A button.

steps.headline: Pick the Tannin you want to use.
steps.description: The type of Tannin you use will depend on the rarity of your current item. If you want to go from a white item to green, you will need hemming. Green to blue items require embroidery and blue to purple needs elegant lining. Finally, purple to orange requires dreugh wax.

steps.headline: Pick the number of Tannin you want to use.
steps.description: Do this by going left and right on your controller on the improvement tab. The percentage of the improvement is based on how many Tannin you use. For instance, if you wanted to go from a white to green item, you can use between 1 and 5 hemmings. If you only use one, your improvement chance is going to only be 20%. If you fail, your item and the tannin will be destroyed. So your best bet is to always use the most Tannin per improvement that you can to get a 100% chance of succeeding.

steps.headline: Hit the X button to improve your item.
steps.description: You will now have the item that you created (as long as it doesn’t fail) and will gain valuable Clothing experience.
